fields.summary: ELB goes out of service if clocks of instance not in sync with cloud

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: ELB's won't work properly when they don't have internet connectivity. As part of the ELB image we setup public NTP servers for time sync. In enterprise environments its not guaranteed that instances can reach the internet. This issue can cause drift in the clock on the ELB and as a result instances registered against it will remain OutofService. What we see in the servo.log for such an ELB: {code}403 ForbiddenMessage was generated in the future (tim es in UTC): Timestamp=Wed Aug 21 06:12:38 EEST 2013Message was generated in the fut ure (times in UTC): Timestamp=Wed Aug 21 06:12:38 EEST 2013 failed to query the elb service: BotoServerError: 403 Forbidden 403 ForbiddenMessage was generated in the future (tim es in UTC): Timestamp=Wed Aug 21 06:12:38 EEST 2013Message was generated in the fut ure (times in UTC): Timestamp=Wed Aug 21 06:12:38 EEST 2013 failed to find the loadbalancers 403 Forbidden 403 ForbiddenMessage was generated in the future (tim es in UTC): Timestamp=Wed Aug 21 06:12:38 EEST 2013Message was generated in the fut ure (times in UTC): Timestamp=Wed Aug 21 06:12:38 EEST 2013 failed to report the cloudwatch metrics: BotoServerError: 403 Forbidden 403 ForbiddenMessage was generated in the future (tim es in UTC): Timestamp=Wed Aug 21 06:12:38 EEST 2013Message was generated in the fut ure (times in UTC): Timestamp=Wed Aug 21 06:12:38 EEST 2013 403 Forbidden {code} Ideally we need to support configurable NTP parameters via the cloud properties. This should be documented as a known issue for 3.3.1.
fields.summary: ELBs fail because of lack of internet connection due to NTP

comments.body: [~mspaulding] I guess we can simply add 169.254.169.254 to the ntp.conf of the servo image, right?
That sounds like it will work, though if that address is not configurable then this solution is no more than a band-aid that makes it even harder to get ELB working in system and static modes.

That's possibility. There are other parts of servo that assumes non-system/static modes. So if we ever decide to support ELB in those modes, we will revisit them all anyway. Plus, this change will be easily detectable in system/static modes (so won't go unfixed).

Fix committed:
https://github.com/eucalyptus/load-balancer-image/commit/e38b5fee209bbf1ed93d99dced51cc6c1c4a354f

Log output from load balancer image:

{noformat}
Sep  6 23:25:06 euca-172-27-226-173 ntpdate[1098]: step time server 169.254.169.254 offset 25201.331785 sec
Sep  6 23:25:06 euca-172-27-226-173 ntpd[1106]: ntpd 4.2.4p8@1.1612-o Fri Feb 22 11:23:27 UTC 2013 (1)
Sep  6 23:25:06 euca-172-27-226-173 ntpd[1107]: precision = 0.139 usec
Sep  6 23:25:06 euca-172-27-226-173 ntpd[1107]: Listening on interface #0 wildcard, 0.0.0.0#123 Disabled
Sep  6 23:25:06 euca-172-27-226-173 ntpd[1107]: Listening on interface #1 wildcard, ::#123 Disabled
Sep  6 23:25:06 euca-172-27-226-173 ntpd[1107]: Listening on interface #2 lo, ::1#123 Enabled
Sep  6 23:25:06 euca-172-27-226-173 ntpd[1107]: Listening on interface #3 eth0, fe80::d20d:96ff:fe8a:402c#123 Enabled
Sep  6 23:25:06 euca-172-27-226-173 ntpd[1107]: Listening on interface #4 lo, 127.0.0.1#123 Enabled
Sep  6 23:25:06 euca-172-27-226-173 ntpd[1107]: Listening on interface #5 eth0, 172.27.226.173#123 Enabled
Sep  6 23:25:06 euca-172-27-226-173 ntpd[1107]: Listening on routing socket on fd #22 for interface updates
Sep  6 23:25:06 euca-172-27-226-173 ntpd[1107]: kernel time sync status 2040
{noformat}
I don't think this is a very good fix.  This doesn't address the use case of the folks who are hit by this issue, it adds another requirement on them to use the CLC as an NTP server.
[~lwade] wondering why this doesn't address the use case of folks? So the root cause of the problem was that ELB instances can't talk to CLC due to clock drift (message auth failure).

[~spark] because you'd have to configure the CLC as a forwarder, so it introduces another requirement.  The root cause is that the ELB instances cannot talk to public NTP servers, not private ones inside a users environment.  Here we just let them use the CLC, not let them use their own NTP servers of choice.
[~lwade] Ok, so they have their own private NTP pool? That's the valuable information and I agree then that we should change the fix by adding configurable properties.
[~mspaulding] I'm going to add properties, have it default CLC's IP, and let the value available as user-data to ELB instances. Can you modify your fix to use it during the service startup?
[~spark], thanks, this solution sounds perfect.  Can we make it a comma separated list or such like? Users will want to specify multiple servers in some cases.
[~lwade] yes we'll do.

[~mspaulding] the fix is committed to testing. there will be user data with this format: "ntp_server:host1,host2,..,;" only when admins configured the ntp server address manually. By default, the instances will not  get the "ntp_server" in the user-data, in which case we don't modify the NTP client setting. If you want, I can change the servo scripts as well. Let me know..

Thanks [~spark]. I can make the required changes for the ntp server. I think this will require us to have servo control the ntpd daemon directly instead of having it run by the init script. If user data for the ntp server is not passed to servo then it will default to using the CLC as the ntp server.

[~mspaulding]I'm fine with both, but I think init script is also possible because user-data is one-time setting. I think it's better to actually not change ntpd setting when no ntp_server is found in user-data. This way we'll not require clc to run ntpd when users' vm has Internet connection. Only when users find issues, then they will change it.

[~spark], my concern about using the init script is that servo does not have access to write to the /etc/ntp.conf file. We would need to write a separate config file and then run ntpd passing the config file as an option. An alternative would be to change the command line arguments in /etc/sysconfig/ntpd to point to a config file that the servo has write access to. Servo could then copy the /etc/ntp.conf file to this location and modify it if necessary.
[~mspaulding] Ok I didn't know about the file permission issue. I'm fine with any approaches you choose.

Submitted pull request for load-balancer-servo to add an ntp-update script that is run on boot of the instance:

https://github.com/eucalyptus/load-balancer-servo/pull/1
https://github.com/eucalyptus/load-balancer-servo/pull/2
Hey guys, I don't see in the pull requests how this information is passed as userdata? Is there anything you can point me to in regards to the cloud property?  Thanks.
ping [~mclark], can you please confirm fix version.
FIx verified via [~dshekhawat]'s work on the issue. I'm just moving it along.
